Award.AbstractNarration:
Mutualisms occur when species interact with each other in a way that benefits both; a familiar example is pollination by bees. Essential to the survival of many species, mutualisms are critically important for the functioning of natural ecosystems. When many different mutualists depend on each other, they create complex webs of interactions, known as mutualistic networks. A key feature of these networks is the strength of each pair of interactions, which is difficult to measure accurately when there are many of them. This study provides such measurements for a mutualistic network of fruit-eating animals and the fruiting plants whose seeds they disperse. Specifically, birds, bats and primates feeding in fig trees will be studied in Madagascar. Interaction strengths and the role of these interactions in the community will be investigated by field observations, experiments, laboratory assays, and statistical analyses.

In addition, the project team will take practical steps to increase public awareness of mutualisms, improve ecological training of students, and promote effective conservation planning. In particular, the team will share project results with the public through outreach programs and training for middle- and high-school students and teachers, and will enhance ecological training of undergraduate and graduate students via mentorship programs coordinated with the research. Finally, they will increase capacity for science-based conservation planning by working with land managers in the United States and Madagascar.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mutualisms, the mutually beneficial interactions that occur between pairs of organisms, are essential to the survival of many species and are critically important for the functioning of natural ecosystems.  Mutualisms serve as links joining large suites of species in complex webs of interactions known as mutualistic networks.  A mutualistic network is defined by its set of interaction strengths – the magnitudes of the effects of each species’ population on each other.  However, due to the inherent complexity of such networks, the accurate measurement of their interaction strengths has been difficult, and this difficulty has hindered broader understanding of ecological communities.  This project, therefore, used intensive study of a model community to gain highly detailed data on interaction strengths in mutualistic networks and to improve understanding of how ecological communities are maintained and how they change over time.

We examined frugivory/seed dispersal mutualisms, a central ecological feature of tropical forests and one that is essential to these forests’ maintenance and regeneration.  In these mutualisms, frugivores (fruit-eating animals) visit fruit-bearing trees to obtain food, and in the process they inadvertently carry seeds to habitats suitable for tree growth.  Thus, this mutualism provides both the food needed for frugivores’ survival and the seed dispersal service needed for trees’ reproduction.  This project targeted mutualistic interactions between fig trees and frugivorous animals (primates [lemurs], birds, and fruit bats) in a tropical forest in Madagascar.  Interaction strengths and their role in the community were investigated via an integrated approach involving field observation and experimentation, laboratory assays, and statistical and network analysis.  This approach enabled us to collect data on mutualistic interactions in our network in several formats, ranging from the simplified surrogate metrics for interaction strength that have typically been used in the literature to new, highly detailed metrics that provide more ecological information on the strength of these interactions.  To investigate temporal variation in interaction strengths, we collected these data across the dry season and over multiple years.            
Our results suggest interaction strengths in the network are highly skewed, with many weak and a few very strong interactions.  The particular patterns of interactions, however, varied considerably with the particular metric used to measure interaction strength, suggesting that some surrogate metrics for interaction strength that are commonly used in the literature may poorly characterize mutualistic networks and that significant insights into mutualistic networks may be gained through the collection of detailed and ecologically relevant data on interaction strengths.  In addition, our results indicated that both the importance of particular species to the network, and the structural properties of the network as a whole, varied across the season and between years.  Such temporal variation has important implications for the consistency expected in species interactions across ecological contexts, and for ecological understanding of community structure and dynamics.  One such implication is that assuming – as is often done in the literature – that networks or network properties are static may be misleading.  Understanding of mutualistic networks, therefore, may be advanced by examining networks under multiple contexts and evaluating which factors influence their structure to the greatest extent.  In our system factors such as species composition, spatial dispersion of interacting partners, and fruit availability correlate with key measures of network structure.      
The project has also resulted in other outcomes that have improved understanding of the ecology of the ecological community and that may facilitate its conservation.  Specifically, the project has improved estimates of the densities of fig and frugivore species in the network, detected key factors influencing frugivore diets, identified drivers of natural resource use in the system, clarified how disturbance and anthropogenic exploitation influence the plant and frugivore communities, and determined the effects of habitat degradation on mutualistic networks.
  
Finally, the project team also took practical steps to increase public awareness of and interest in mutualistic interactions, improve ecological training, and promote effective conservation planning in the United States and Madagascar.  Thus far, the project has resulted in 12 published scientific articles and 10 scientific presentations.  We provided training opportunities for 39 participants, including 34 early-career scientists, 28 of whom are from groups traditionally underrepresented in ecology.  We provided research opportunities for 14 graduate students and 13 undergraduate students.  Most of these students engaged substantively in core aspects of the research, and 15 early-career scientists have served thus far as lead authors or co-authors on scientific publications.  During the project, we also integrated project results into university courses, led public outreach events, developed recommendations to address barriers to scientific education in the Malagasy school system, engaged in reforestation activities with the local community, contributed data to support conservation and management activities, and increased capacity for science-based conservation planning among land managers in Madagascar.
